Arg.V:
#!/bin/bash
function updatepk() { if [ ! -z $1 ]; then if [ -e /var/run/yum.pid ];then exit 10 fi result=`yum -y update $1 2>&1` status=$? commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: command not found"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: No such file or directory"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "lock /var/run/yum.pid"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "/var/run/yum.pid: another copy is running"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "There was an error communicating with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "This system is not registered with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "No Repositories Available to Set Up"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "Error Class Code: 9 Error Class Info: Invalid System Credentials"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isscriptletfailed=`echo $result | grep -E "error:" | grep -E "scriptlet failed, exit status 255"` if [ "$isscriptletfailed" != "" ]; then exit 6 fi if [ $status -ne 0 ];then exit 7 fi fi } updatepk libcacard
exit 0

exit 0

Vulnerability.Title: qemu-kvm bug fix update
Vulnerability.Description: KVM (Kernel-based Virtual Machine) is a full virtualization solution for Linux on AMD64 and Intel 64 systems. qemu-kvm is the user-space component for running virtual machines using KVM. This update fixes the following bugs: Prior to this update, the KVM utility executed demanding routing update system calls every time it performed an MSI vector mask/unmask operation. Consequently, guests running legacy systems, such as Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5, could under some circumstances experience significant slowdown. With this update, the routing system calls during mask or unmask operations are skipped, and the performance of legacy guests is now more consistent. (BZ#1110693, BZ#1110695) Previously, qemu-kvm spent a long time in a loop that is only needed for devices that did not use coalesced I/O. Consequently, timeouts in the block device initialization scripts occurred. With this update, qemu-kvm detects devices that do not need coalesced I/O and skips the loop, thus fixing the timeouts. (BZ#1124660) When using VLANs with OpenBSD guests, RX filter was incorrect. As a consequence, an empty VLAN table was reported where in fact VLAN filtering was disabled, which prevented VM guest from starting. Two upstream patches have been back-ported, which fix a boundary issue in the visiting VLAN table. As a result, VM guest starts successfully. (BZ#1130149) Users of qemu-kvm are advised to upgrade to these updated packages, which fix these bugs. After installing this update, shut down all running virtual machines. Once all virtual machines have shut down, start them again for this update to take effect. Note for remediation: Please disable the SELinux for RHEL 4/5 when repairing, or some rpm packages will fail to install.
